occurrences.line_text: To haue before bewitched all mens sight;
And dimmed sight with pale and deadly hew
In secret shadow, farre from all mens sight:
And with the sight amazd, forgat his furious forse.
Where haue ye bene thus long out of my sight?
For since mine eye your ioyous sight did mis,
And halfe ashamed, wondred at the sight:
There waiting long, to win the wished sight
Themselues to setten forth to straungers sight:
With proud foes sight my sorrow to renew:
The wise Southsayer seeing so sad sight,
She greatly grew amazed at the sight,
And sight of men, since his late luckelesse fray.
A ruefull sight, as could be seene with eie;
And made ensample of their mournefull sight
Hauing escapt so sad ensamples in his sight.
And Phoebus flying so most shamefull sight,
All stand amazed at so vncouth sight,
The fearefull Dame all quaked at the sight,
To tell the sad sight, which mine eies haue red:
(A sory sight) arraung'd in battell new,
With sturdie steps came stalking in his sight,
Ye dreary instruments of dolefull sight,
And let eternall night so sad [sight] fro me hide.
For earthly sight can nought but sorow breed,
But all that was not such, as seemd in sight,
An huge great Dragon horrible in sight,
Missing the marke of his misaymed sight
Themselues in vaine: for since that glauncing sight,
For his eye sight him failed long ygo,
But very vncouth sight was to behold,
And loe that wicked woman in your sight,
And eke her feete most monstrous were in sight;
Such is the face of falshood, such the sight
Dismayd with that deformed dismall sight,
With thine owne bloud to price his bloud, here shed in sight.
The sight whereof so throughly him dismaid,
That could haue dazd the rash beholders sight,
Not all so chearefull seemed she of sight,
And through great age had lost their kindly sight,
Whose sight my feeble soule doth greatly cheare:
That sight thereof bred cold congealed feare:
No wonder if he wondred at the sight,
The sight with idle feare did them dismay,
So faire and fresh that Lady shewd her selfe in sight.
Did wonder much at her celestiall sight:
At suddeinnesse of that vnwarie sight,
That easie was t'inuegle weaker sight:
But yet so sterne and terrible in sight,
To tell this ruefull tale; thy sight could win thee grace.
Shee sight from bottome of her wounded brest,
And from so heauie sight his head did wreath,
Was suddein vanished out of his sight:
That quite bereau'd the rash beholders sight:
She seemd, when she presented was to sight,
Soone as my loathed loue appeard in sight,
And stoutly prou'd thy puissaunce here in sight;
That Guyon much disdeignd so loathly sight.
Him deeming dead, as then he seemd in sight,
But when as Guyon of that land had sight,
Your cruell eyes endure so pitteous sight,
For much he wondred at that vncouth sight;
Of griesly hew, and fowle ill fauour'd sight;
Those pretious hils from straungers enuious sight,
And though him selfe were at the sight dismayd,
From heauens sight, and powre of all which the[m] pursew.
But gnawing Gealosie out of their sight
Deformed creatures, horrible in sight,
To wonder at the sight: for till that day,
In senselesse dreame; which sight at first him sore aghast.
Behold this heauie sight, thou reuerend Sire,
And his slow eyes beguiled of their sight,
But you, faire Sir, whose honorable sight
Sith of that Goddesse I haue sought the sight,
They thither marcht: but when they came in sight,
For neuer had they seene so straunge a sight.
But somwhat sad, and solemne eke in sight,
Ere long they rowed were quite out of sight,
Those same against the bulwarke of the Sight
Was much dismayed with that dreadfull sight:
Made of a dead mans skull, that seem'd a ghastly sight.
Ne wist he, what to thinke of that same sight,
That he began to doubt his dazeled sight,
Depending from on high, dreadfull to sight,
With her false eyes fast fixed in his sight,
At sight whereof the people stand aghast:
Eftsoones them brought vnto their Ladies sight,
So shamelesse beauty soone becomes a loathy sight.
And much more strangely gan to loue his sight,
It vertue had, to shew in perfect sight,
Streight way with dreames, and with fantasticke sight
Great Neptune stood amazed at their sight,
Which when the Prince beheld, a lothfull sight,
And out of sight escaped at the least;
For soone as he was vanisht out of sight,
Saw neuer liuing eye more heauy sight,
Her hart was pierst with pittie at the sight,
Which, chearefull signe did send vnto her sight,
In mischiefe, was much moued at so pitteous sight.
The sight whereof did greatly him adaw,
But greedily long gaping at the sight,
Thought with that sight him much to haue reliued;
Extremely ioyed in so happie sight,
To be no vision, nor fantasticke sight,
The sight whereof in his congealed flesh,
He therein saw that yrkesome sight, which smote
For shame, but more for feare of his grim sight,
And offered faire gifts t'allure her sight,
But in close bowre her mewes from all mens sight,
With great amazement of so wondrous sight,
That of his Lady they might haue the sight,
All his demeasnure from his sight did hyde:
Out of his sight her selfe once to absent.
That with thy charmes the sharpest sight doest bind,
Did clap her hands, and ioyed at that dolefull sight.
And euer his faint hart much earned at the sight.
That seem'd no helpe for him was left in liuing sight.
With great indignaunce he that sight forsooke,
And fed on fodder, to beguile her sight.
That wondrous sight faire Britomart amazed,
Full of sad signes, fearefull to liuing sight;
And a wide wound therein (O ruefull sight)
That sight of such a chaunge her much dismayd.
That it prodigious seemes in common peoples sight.
For she could d'on so manie shapes in sight,
But that in all those knights and ladies sight,
After each beautie, that appeard in sight,
They which from shore behold the dreadfull sight
Glad man was he to see that ioyous sight,
And yet vncertaine by such outward sight,
Did by great fortune get of her the sight;
Though sad and sorie for so heauy sight,
So fresh he seemed and so fierce in sight;
That downe he fell as dead in all mens sight:
Of th'vncouth sight, as he some ghost had seene,
And lo shee shall be placed here in sight,
And hearts quite robbed with so glorious sight,
At him, that first appeared in his sight:
That euery one gan shun his dreadfull sight,
For Cambell victour was in all mens sight,
Next did Sir Triamond vnto their sight
The sight of whom once seene did all the rest dismay.
That all men wondred at the vncouth sight,
He like a monstrous Gyant seem'd in sight,
Like to the ruddie morne appeard in sight,
Did comfort take, or in his troubled sight
Time to my will, and from his wrathfull sight
And euermore when with regardfull sight
Which drery sight the gentle Squire espying,
Her noble heart with sight thereof was fild
And follow'd fast: but when he came in sight,
A foule and loathly creature sure in sight,
Then faire grew foule, and foule grew faire in sight,
That them to view had bene an vncouth sight;
At last when they were passed out of sight,
From that his cruell foe, that him pursewd in sight.
But by the powre of his infectious sight,
To see the sight perforce, that both her eyes were loth.
And gnasht his yron tuskes at that displeasing sight.
At sight thereof she was with terror queld,
Yet seem'd full aged by his outward sight,
That nothing like himselfe he seem'd in sight.
Foure times his place he shifted hath in sight,
And makes them like himselfe in glorious sight,
That euen wilde beasts did feare his awfull sight,
A sorie sight, as euer seene with eye;
Much was he moued at that ruefull sight;
And on his steed her set, to beare her out of sight.
The sight whereof the Lady sore adrad,
Deuided be betwixt you here in sight,
Hemd in with waters like a wall in sight;
Sith thou misdeem'st so much of things in sight?
The trembling foule dismayd with dreadfull sight
And thether also came in open sight
The sight whereof did all with gladnesse fill:
All that behold so strange prodigious sight,
And in the sight of all men cleane disgraced,
To whom when he approched neare in sight,
(An vncouth sight) he plainely then descride
Made them all enter in before her sight,
Before the city gate, in open sight;
As she had seene that day a disauenterous sight.
At sight thereof his cruell minded hart
Like as a Puttocke hauing spyde in sight
With sight whereof she was dismayd right sore,
But that she saw there present in her sight,
That way betwixt them none appeares in sight;
And doubtfully dismayd through that so vncouth sight.
Therefore thus one of them, who seem'd in sight
Through great astonishment of that strange sight;
On th'other side her foe appeared soone in sight.
Which dreadfull sight, when all her warlike traine
Where when she saw that lothly vncouth sight,
At sight thereof abasht with secrete shame,
Ah my deare Lord, what sight is this (quoth she)
The worlds whole rule for Cleopatras sight.
Where soone as his proud wife of her had sight,
For doubt to be discouered by his sight,
Durst not endure their sight, but fled from place to place.
So did the sight thereof their sense dismay,
The dreadfull sight did them so sore affray,
He caused them be hung in all mens sight,
That deadly daunger seem'd in all mens sight,
Directed in, and shewed all the sight:
But at the sight of these, those were a while debard.
But when her owne two sonnes she had in sight,
Now rise againe, at this your ioyous sight.
To which when now they gan approch in sight,
Before his feete, in all that peoples sight;
And much dismayd with that dismayfull sight,
As neither glad nor sorie for their sight;
To so faire Ladie, as ye seeme in sight,
And forward marched to a towne in sight.
That could haue frayd one with the very sight,
But th'Elfin swayne, that oft had seene like sight,
Whose sight to her is greatest crosse, may fall,
The wisest sight, to thinke gold that is bras.
Who whenas each of other had a sight,
Which haynous sight when Calidore beheld,
But Calidore, that was more quicke of sight,
Whereof befell, what now is in your sight.
Long fed his greedie eyes with the faire sight
Which sorie sight when Calidore did vew
And from her sory hart few heauie words forth sigh't.
But sigh't and sorrow'd for her louer deare,
He deepely sigh't, and groaned inwardly,
To giue faire colour to that Ladies cause in sight.
Her wauering lust after her wandring sight,
Vprear'd her head to see that chearefull sight.
Yet flowing fresh, as moued with the sight,
Till that his Ladies sight he mote attaine,
That mote to all men seeme an vncouth sight;
He came, whose couert stopt his further sight,
So now they be arriued both in sight
At sight thereof, and from her presence flee:
Shun secresie, and talke in open sight:
And with her garment couering him from sight,
Gotten great worship in this worldes sight.
He much was daunted with so dismall sight;
So different from that, which earst ye seem'd in sight?
He would haue backe retyred from that sight,
Of all her gifts, that pleasde each liuing sight,
Full many a one for me deepe groand and sigh't,
Vnto some carrion offered to his sight,
Those villeins vew'd with loose lasciuious sight,
He mote perceiue a litle dawning sight
With sight whereof soone cloyd, and long deluded
Like to one sight, which Calidore did vew?
There he did see, that pleased much his sight,
Much wondred Calidore at this straunge sight,
The vanisht all away out of his sight,
Thus to bereaue thy Loues deare sight from thee:
Most sorrowfull, most sad, that euer sigh't,
At sight whereof his barbarous heart was fired,
The sight of whom, though now decayd and mard,
And halfe enraged at that ruefull sight;
He chauft, he grieu'd, he fretted, and he sigh't,
Whereof she long had lackt the wishfull sight,
The litle babe, to take thereof a sight.
And seeing it, much wondred at the sight;
And horribly misshapes with vgly sightes,
Is tost with troubled sights and fancies weake,
Vnto his guest, who after troublous sights
And stroue for to amaze the weaker sights;
Sad be the sights, and bitter fruits of warre,
Emongst the rest of those same ruefull sights,
Thus said; Behold th'ensamples in our sights,
And shewd him many sights, that courage cold could reare.
With their light wings, the sights of semblants vaine:
Yet all those sights, and all that else I saw,
in all the Ladies sights.
The goodly seruice, the deuicefull sights,
And what a glorious shew he made in all their sights.
A booke, that was both signd and seald with blood,
The Sarazins shield, signe of the conqueroure.
And whally eyes (the signe of gelosy,)
Saint George of mery England, the signe of victoree.
That signe of last outbreathed life did seeme,
Glad signe of victorie and peace in all their land.
But rather y Scuith gogh, signe of sad crueltee.
Some land-marke seem'd to be, or signe of sundry way.
If any puffe of breath, or signe of sence she fand.
The surest signe, whereby ye may her know,
Which, chearefull signe did send vnto her sight,
Signe of nigh battell, or got victory;
In signe of silence, as to heare a play,
Yet saw her not nor signe of her good speed,
There was the signe of antique Babylon,
A signe which did to him the victorie assure.
The signe whereof yet stain'd his bloudy lips afore.
Ne signe of sence did shew, ne common wit,
In signe of true subiection to her powre,
Willd him to stay, and signe of truce did make:
And tooke with him the head, the signe of shame.
Ne euer shewed signe of foule disloyalty.
His foot he set on his vile necke, in signe
Ne euer shewed signe of rancour or of iarre.
And saw the signes, that deadly tydings spake,
Gaue goodly gifts, the signes of gratefull mynd,
Suffice it heare by signes to vnderstand
By certaine signes here set in sundry place
With her two crooked handes she signes did make,
Gaue signes of grudge and discontentment vaine:
The secret signes of kindled lust appeare,
Was fowly ra'st, that none the signes might see;
Her wanton eyes, ill signes of womanhed,
By knowen signes and passions, which I see,
But shewd by outward signes, that dread her sence did daze.
Aye me, (said Paridell) the signes be sad,
By such close signes they secret way did make
With other signes of sorrow and impatient teene.
Full of sad signes, fearefull to liuing sight;
Then shewing forth signes of their fathers blood,
The signes of anguish one mote plainely read,
Yet weend by secret signes of manlinesse,
At which he wondred much, when all those signes he fond.
Yet chearefull signes he shewed outwardly.
Mongst those twelue signes, which nightly we doe see
But Artegall by signes perceiuing plaine,
And these the signes, (so shewed forth his wounds)
They shouted loud, and signes of gladnesse all did shew.
Bewrayd the signes of feature excellent:
By outward signes, (as well he might) did see,
By many signes, which she described had,
By certaine signes he plainely him descryde,
Which earst he left, he signes vnto them made,
By signes, by lookes, and all his other gests.
By speaking signes, as he them best could frame;
Of this her groome, which he by signes did reede;
And sought, by making signes, him to asswage:
Plaine signes in him of life and liuelihead.
He mote perceiue by signes, which he did fynd,
She found at last by very certaine signes,
Through her thin weed their places only signifide.
Like as Osyris signifies the Sunne.
With quaking hands, and other signs of feare:
Whose prayses hauing slept in silence long,
Wrapt in eternall silence farre from enemyes.
He mumbled soft, but would not all his silence breake.
Thence turning backe in silence soft they stole,
There raignd a solemne silence ouer all,
Yet sithens silence lesseneth not my fire,
Yet forst, at last he made through silence suddein breach.
At last his solemne silence thus he brake,
Now whenas all the world in silence deepe
And solemne silence ouer all that place:
In silence and in sleepe themselues did shroud,
In signe of silence, as to heare a play,
His sodaine silence, which he long had pent,
Soft Silence, and submisse Obedience,
In solitary silence far from wight,
As if that by his silence he would make
His deare affect with silence did restraine,
But holding vp his hands, with silence mercie prayd.
And to the Paynims lodging comes with silent pace.
Which sparckling on the silent waues, does seeme more bright.
Couered with secret cloud of silent night,
Or doth thy iustice sleepe, and silent ly?
Vnto her selfe her silent prayers did impart.
That seemd like silke and siluer wouen neare,
But neither silke nor siluer therein did appeare.
All in a vele of silke and siluer thin,
Wouen with gold and silke so close and nere,
His garment neither was of silke nor say,
And alwaies in her hand two clewes of silke she twynd.
All in a Camis light of purple silke
All in a silken Camus lylly whight,
With silken curtens and gold couerlets,
Did now but freshly spring, and silken blossomes beare.
But lightly rased her soft silken skin,
But lapped vp her silken leaues most chaire,
In silken samite she was light arayd,
And like a silken veile in compasse round
That all her silken garments did with bloud bestaine.
Like as a flowre, whose silken leaues small,
Her paps, which like white silken pillowes were,
Of sundry flowres, with silken ribbands tyde,
That like a rose her silken leaues did faire vnfold.
Silly old man, that liues in hidden cell,
On silly Dame, subiect to hard mischaunce,
Me silly maid away with him he bare,
A silly man, in simple weedes forworne,
Not caring how, her silly life to saue,
With silly weake old woman thus to fight.
She wist not, silly Mayd, what she did aile,
With silly Virgin by aduenture brought
Against the silly clowne, who dead through feare,
The silly virgin stroue him to withstand,
A silly Pilgrim driuen to distresse,
The silly man that in the thicket lay
Litle for him to haue one silly lasse:
That Coridon it was, the silly shepherds hynd.
Both Silo this, and Iordan did excell,
Y cladd in mightie armes and siluer shielde,
In siluer deaw his euer-drouping hed,
The other all with siluer ouercast;
And siluer shield vpon his coward brest
His siluer shield, now idle maisterlesse;
And siluer Cynthia wexed pale and faint,
How ill it sits with that same siluer hed
From whence the riuer Dee as siluer cleene
Vpon her arme a siluer anchor lay,
Vpon her siluer anchor, as was meet;
From which fast trickled forth a siluer flood,
That seemd like silke and siluer wouen neare,
But neither silke nor siluer therein did appeare.
Vpright he rode, and in his siluer shield
Now hath faire Phoebe with her siluer face
A siluer sound, that heauenly musicke seemd to make.
Fountaines of gold and siluer to abound,
And in the midst thereof a siluer seat,
Ne sittest downe on that same siluer stoole,
How oft do they, their siluer bowers leaue,
Were made, and set in siluer sockets bright,
Bright Scolopendraes, arm'd with siluer scales,
So pure and shiny, that the siluer flood
That themselues dipping in the siluer dew,
The siluer sounding instruments did meet
All in a vele of silke and siluer thin,
Breakes forth her siluer beames, and her bright hed
With price of siluer shall his kingdome buy,
Their watchet mantles frindgd with siluer round,
Her siluer buskins from her nimble thigh,
In siluer sockets, shyning like the skyes,
Now Bacchus fruit out of the siluer plate
Did shine with siluer, and shoot forth his beame.
Without adorne of gold or siluer bright,
Was drawne forth, and in siluer basin layd,
His siluer Harpe in hand, and shortly friends them make.
Deawed with siluer drops, through sweating sore;
With siluer streames amongst the linnen stray'd;
As with a robe, with her owne siluer haire,
Deawed with siluer drops, that trickled downe alway.
That seem'd like siluer, sprinckled here and theare
Her siluer feet, faire washt against this day:
With golden hands and siluer feete beside,
And eke her feete, those feete of siluer trye,
Wouen vppon with siluer, subtly wrought,
First rings his siluer Bell t'each sleepy wight,
Like coles, that through a siluer Censer sparkle bright.
All clad in linnen robes with siluer hemd;
The which was framed all of siluer fine,
Hemd all about with fringe of siluer twine.
And royall gifts of gold and siluer wrought,
And here and there shooting forth siluer streames,
The Kingdomes care, with a white siluer hed,
Where it in siluer bowre does hidden ly
Of Lincolne greene, belayd with siluer lace;
The whyles his Lord in siluer slomber lay,
Whose siluer lockes bedeckt his beard and hed,
But all the night in siluer sleepe I spend,
His siluer waues did softly tumble downe,
Simple in shew, and voyde of malice bad,
With chaunge of cheare the seeming simple maid
Her vp he tooke, too simple and too trew,
And simple truth subdue auenging wrong?
A silly man, in simple weedes forworne,
My simple selfe, and seruice euermore;
But simple true, and eke vnfained sweet,
Too high a ditty for my simple song;
But vnder simple shew and semblant plaine
Whose simple answere, wanting colours faire
(O too high ditty for my simple rime.)
A simple mayd, and worke so haynous tort,
Dwelt simple truth in seemely fashion.
And he too simple euer to surprise
And eke my selfe, albe I simple such,
And pardon simple man, that rash did him displease.
In simple truth and blamelesse chastitie,
The which did seeme vnto my simple doome,
But simple Truth did rayne, and was of all admyred.
How he mis-led the simple peoples traine,
And loued simple truth and stedfast honesty.
Sith he cannot expresse his simple minde,
Such homely what, as serues the simple clowne,
Him to inuite vnto his simple home;
This simple sort of life, that shepheards lead,
Simple and true from couert malice free:
That seem'd to be some sorie simple clowne,
Of this false footman, clokt with simplenesse,
That from her body full of filthie sin
Was sluggish Idlenesse the nourse of sin;
For daring tempt the Queene of heauen to sin;
With beastly sin thought her to haue defilde,
Of his lewd lusts, and late attempted sin,
All they for want of faith, or guilt of sin,
The lenger life, I wote the greater sin,
The greater sin, the greater punishment:
Why then doest thou, O man of sin, desire
Inward corruption, and infected sin,
When sin, and hell, and death do most dismay
For bloud can nought but sin, & wars but sorrowes yield.
As faint through heat, or dight to pleasant sin,
Most sacred virgin, without spot of sin.
Where wicked ghosts do waile their former sin.
So liu'd they euer after in like sin,
As may be worthy of his haynous sin.
To teare his flesh in peeces for his sin.
There written was the purport of his sin,
Did choke the entraunce with a lumpe of sin,
